instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the prediction of RCC status in the related study on the development of a noninvasive diagnostic assay for RCC and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the prediction of RCC status in the related study was the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC). The AUC is a commonly used metric in diagnostic tests and machine learning models to assess the overall performance of the model in distinguishing between two classes (in this case, RCC patients and controls). 

The AUC ranges from 0 to 1, with a value of 0.5 indicating a random prediction and a value of 1 indicating a perfect prediction. In the related study, the AUC was reported to be 0.98, which suggests that the metabolomic panel had a high discriminatory power in predicting RCC status. 

Therefore, the chosen metric, AUC, indicates that the model performed very well in distinguishing between RCC patients and controls, with a high level of accuracy.

instruction: How were machine learning techniques utilized in the development of a noninvasive diagnostic assay for RCC using urine metabolomic profiling?
Output:
Machine learning techniques were utilized in the development of a noninvasive diagnostic assay for RCC using urine metabolomic profiling by analyzing liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) data. The study cohort consisted of 105 RCC patients and 179 controls, which were divided into a model cohort and a test cohort. 

To select discriminatory features, univariate, wrapper, and embedded methods were employed using the model cohort. These methods helped identify the most relevant metabolites for RCC diagnosis. 

Three different machine learning techniques, each with different induction biases, were then used for training and hyperparameter tuning. These techniques were applied to the selected biomarkers and the optimally tuned ML algorithms. 

Finally, the accuracy of RCC status prediction was evaluated using the test cohort. The seven-metabolite panel predicted RCC with 88% accuracy, 94% sensitivity, 85% specificity, and an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.98. 

Overall, machine learning techniques were instrumental in analyzing the metabolomic data and developing a noninvasive diagnostic assay for RCC using urine metabolomic profiling.
